_decoded_content.name: Tension Key (Adaptive Tension Ring)
_decoded_content.description:
This tension key is a hands free method to apply tension to yarn in order to properly crochet/knit. It is designed for those with physical impairments or lack the fine motor control required to apply tension to yarn, but can also be useful for first time learners. 

Alternatives to this tension key include the widespread tension rings. Rings pose a safety concern for those with physical impairments and are often hard to use for those who have experienced stroke. Rings cannot be worn by those with certain types of arthritis as the swelling of the knuckles associated with the condition poses a serious safety risk. 

This 3D print file was designed as a part of the requirements of the Assistive Technology & Home Modification course at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas - Occupational Therapy Doctorate Program. This assignment was done for a grade, however, I intend to continue development in order to perfect it. 

If you have any feedback at all, please contact me at quinlk2@unlv.nevada.edu or leave a comment. I welcome any and all feedback and improvements that can be made.

_decoded_content.details:
Summary

This tension key is a hands free method to apply tension to yarn in order to properly crochet/knit. It is designed for those with physical impairments or lack the fine motor control required to apply tension to yarn, but can also be useful for first time learners.

Alternatives to this tension key include the widespread tension rings. Rings pose a safety concern for those with physical impairments and are often hard to use for those who have experienced stroke. Rings cannot be worn by those with certain types of arthritis as the swelling of the knuckles associated with the condition poses a serious safety risk.

This 3D print file was designed as a part of the requirements of the Assistive Technology & Home Modification course at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas - Occupational Therapy Doctorate Program. This assignment was done for a grade, however, I intend to continue development in order to perfect it.

If you have any feedback at all, please contact me at quinlk2@unlv.nevada.edu or leave a comment. I welcome any and all feedback and improvements that can be made.

Print Settings

Printer Brand:

Prusa

                                            <p class="detail-setting rafts"><strong>Rafts: </strong>                     <div><p>Yes</p></div>

Supports:

No

                                            <p class="detail-setting infill"><strong>Infill: </strong>                     <div><p>15-20%</p></div>



Notes:

Regarding infill, 20% is recommended if it is being permanently affixed to a wheelchair with zip ties. Otherwise, 15% is more than sufficient.

Rafts were used for all of my prints of this device, however, due to the shape it may not be necessary.

For aesthetic purposes, I highly recommend the use of tricolor filament. This is not necessary by any means, but the slant was designed to display tricolor filament.

How To Use

To use this tension key, it first must be affixed to a surface. There are four holes that zipties can be threaded through to semi-permanently attach it to a chair leg, such as a wheelchair armrest. It can also be velcroed, superglued, or tied with a shoelace.

To thread it, place the yarn in either the small notch or the big notch depending in the thickness of the yarn. The tension key is currently uni-directional; the yarn must go in on the flat side and come out towards the two tension bumps.

For chunky yarn, wrap the yarn around the tension bumps in a figure eight fashion.

Alternatives to this tension key include the widespread tension rings. Rings pose a safety concern for those with physical impairments and are often hard to use for those who have experienced stroke. Rings cannot be worn by those with certain types of arthritis as the swelling of the knuckles associated with the condition poses a serious safety risk.

This 3D print file was designed as a part of the requirements of the Assistive Technology & Home Modification course at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas - Occupational Therapy Doctorate Program. This assignment was done for a grade, however, I intend to continue development in order to perfect it.

If you have any feedback at all, please contact me at quinlk2@unlv.nevada.edu or leave a comment. I welcome any and all feedback and improvements that can be made.

Rafts were used for all of my prints of this device, however, due to the shape it may not be necessary.

For aesthetic purposes, I highly recommend the use of tricolor filament. This is not necessary by any means, but the slant was designed to display tricolor filament.

data.content:
To use this tension key, it first must be affixed to a surface. There are four holes that zipties can be threaded through to semi-permanently attach it to a chair leg, such as a wheelchair armrest. It can also be velcroed, superglued, or tied with a shoelace.

To thread it, place the yarn in either the small notch or the big notch depending in the thickness of the yarn. The tension key is currently uni-directional; the yarn must go in on the flat side and come out towards the two tension bumps.

For chunky yarn, wrap the yarn around the tension bumps in a figure eight fashion.
